blocks.text: + + + + +  LINKE SPALTE, hier runter:

(Interrail) Spring 2038. The world has changed. Intelligent systems ensure fair distribution processes, smallest and largest communities interact in feedback loops, peace reigns in dimmed prosperity, and personal technology helps us to cope with complexity. A serene civilization. But it is still exciting to be 18 years old!
blocks.text2: Interrail 2038

blocks.text: + + + + + RECHTE SPALTE, hier runter:

"We learned […] that we should work less on a singular future and more on an endless scenario universe of connections, joints, interstices, and storylines. […] We managed to deal with complexity. Because we stopped changing people and instead built adaptable, viable systems. Locally and globally. Decentralised and centralised."
"There are many futures and futures are tools."
blocks.text2: The future is present, Ludwig Engel, Olaf Grawert

blocks.text:
"We love our time,
Our time, our time
We love our time…
AND HERE IS WHY"
blocks.text2: I love my time, Christopher Roth

blocks.text: "The future is by definition what exceeds our ideas. Still, you should always speculate about the future, because the ways in which you get it wrong and it surprises you, will affect what you think the future is."
blocks.text2: Now Live on Konrad TV, Jeanne Hu and Mark Wigley on Konrad Wachsmann

blocks.text: "It is always a good time for a reality check."
blocks.text2: Reality Check, Leif Randt

blocks.text: "Architecture is the process of creating an output and contributing to the future of the system. Architecture is not the object itself. It is active: to architect."
blocks.text2: After the Collapse: Architecture for the 99%, Park Chan-sol with Suhail Malik

blocks.text: "How to give a political voice to all generations of humans and nonhumans. A roadmap."
blocks.text2: After Zero-Sum: Serenity for Democracy, Joanna Pope with Audrey Tang

blocks.text: "Personal A.I.s are the augmenters of our own intelligence, complementing human capabilities to work together. United, machines and (non)humans are a joint venture and not an opposing force."
blocks.text2: Splendid Isolation, Ludwig Engel

blocks.text: "Data-intensive digital infrastructures allow us to coordinate human activity without relying on the price mechanism. Because we have leveraged the communicative power of digital technologies in order to facilitate and scale up modes of exchange that were suppressed under capitalism. Cooperation instead of competition."
blocks.text2: After Competition: Serenity Cybernetics, Joanna Pope on Evgeny Morozov

blocks.text: "The growth paradigm is not behind us. This new world we believe ourselves to be living in, exists only as an incredibly delicate balancing act between decentralization and recentralization and their multiscalar negotiations and renegotiations."
blocks.text2: On the "Growthocene", Joanna Pope

blocks.text: "A new global currency is re-enforcing human rights."
blocks.text2: The SDR, Andrés Arauz

blocks.text: "New decision-making structures made the financial industry overcome its rigid assessment criteria. It is now capable to understand the social and the economic value of sustainable neighborhood concepts. The common good is part of the equation."
blocks.text2: The end of endlessly endless Questionnaires, Euroboden

blocks.text: "Digital citizenship means protecting the personality rights of citizens in the digital realm."
blocks.text2: On Protecting Digital Identity, Varuna Jael with Ludger Hovestadt

blocks.text: "I remember the days when many architects were afraid of the digital shift, because they believed that architecture was to focus exclusively on the visible."
blocks.text2: Collective Contracts, Finley Hoxha with Diana Alvarez-Marin

blocks.text:
"Ecosystems cannot be owned any longer. Sorry!*

*This deeply affected construction, farming, the productive industry and of course ethics, as ecocide became the worst possible crime."
blocks.text2: Planetary Rights, at Last!, Galaad Van Daele

blocks.text: "Land, water and air belong to everyone."
blocks.text2: Letter of Workers, Guerilla Architects

blocks.text: "Remember the Property Drama? These were the paths to get OUT."
blocks.text2: Architecting Space & Time, 2038 after ExRotaprint and Frei Otto

blocks.text: "All constitutions of the (old) nation states attempted to restrict property by mandating that it must serve the common good. BUT such legal bindings never became part of our shared value system."
blocks.text2: Doubling the Marshmallows, Anna Yeboah

blocks.text: "Architecting is the ordering of correlations by interacting with means of space."
blocks.text2: 100 Jahre Architektieren, Christian Posthofen

blocks.text: "landscape = housing"
blocks.text2: Lucid Sidewalks, Bar Gregoryan & Bee Haven with Mitchell Joachim

blocks.text: "It's all about cycles. Not recycling but reusing. Preserving value."
blocks.text2: Was kostet die Welt?, Sabine Oberhuber & Thomas Rau

blocks.text: "Madaster records which materials are in a building, where they come from and calculates their future financial value. This gives builders and architects the opportunity to design and construct buildings in order to guarantee maximum value retention."
blocks.text2: Material Matters: From Linear to Circular Economy, 2038 after Sabine Oberhuber & Thomas Rau

blocks.text: "Architecture in a feedback loop with reality: social consequences are managed (including contingency), based on real-time data of global resource availability and local community needs."
blocks.text2: Game Changer, Aang Nkurunziza & Cédric Libert

blocks.text: "There was a radical change in the entire production chain and global logistics of food. The sharp decline in meat consumption and highly valued products began in the 2020s and snowballed into world wide dietary change and then an economic epiphany."
blocks.text2: Food for thought and justice, Marlo Wang with Charlotte Malterre-Barthes

blocks.text: "TENTACULAR THINKING derives from autonomous learning. TENTACULAR THINKING creates very diverse knowledges. TENTACULAR THINKING connects architecture with various other fields."
blocks.text2: Autonomous Learning, Samira Lenzin

blocks.text: "How to build feminist digital green cities. A manual for alternatives."
blocks.text2: After Rebellion: The Serene City, Joanna Pope on Francesca Bria

blocks.text: "All points of view converge in the African house, the place where everything is said."
blocks.text2: 8 Principals of Spacial Organsation, Sénamé Koffi Agbodjinou

blocks.text: "*My+our+their* body is patchwork, stitching  together, *We+us+I* back-translation, respond with snippets of code, letters recycled from multiple text corpora *I+us+you*, borrowed, nothing wasted, Frankenalgorithm."
blocks.text2: Said the Bot to the Computer, Goda Klumbyte & Loren Britton

blocks.text: "Multi-species urbanism means everybody and everything has a voice. Rivers, trees, bees, you, me, we all have voices and thus we have rights!"
blocks.text2: Thriving is a multi-species right, Caroline Nevejan

blocks.text: "Take the human out of the center! Being managed by the environment rather than managing the environment."
blocks.text2: The Architect as a planetary Gardener, Ferdinand Ludwig, Daniel Schönle

blocks.text: "How can you be supportive of the people who care for you, so that they know that their support system matters? Matters for the whole community."
blocks.text2: The Hologram, Cassie Thornton

blocks.text: "We know young people care about the planet and the space they inhabit. Fortunately, there are always young people around."
blocks.text2: Letter of Workers, Lara Verena Bellenghi

blocks.text: "And don't think in fixed objects! It's much riskier than thinking in open processes. Fixed entities remove all possibilities for future change and are unable to adapt."
blocks.text2: The Architect as a planetary Gardener, Ferdinand Ludwig & Daniel Schönle

blocks.text: "This might seem counterintuitive, but it's science."
blocks.text2: The Malaria Houses, 2038 after Jakob Brandtberg Knudsen, Lorenz von Seidlein

blocks.text: "Afrofuturism was about solidarity and transnational thinking. At times, when the ‘first-world’ lost unity, the African Union got it right. Now, their models are distributed and implemented on a planetary scale."
blocks.text2: Timbuktu Papers, Lukas Kubina

blocks.text: "Culture is a fundamental right, inclusive in the very moment it exists."
blocks.text2: La normalità era il problema, Rebiennale / R3B Giulio Grillo

blocks.text: "X crossed the square, breathing in the air of a new city and no longer stressed about walking down Lista di Spagna, which had ceased to be the embodiment of everything they hated about the old Venice, bullshit stands, bullshit restaurants, bullshit shops."
blocks.text2: Sette scene da Venezia, S.a.L.E. Docks

blocks.text: (Test) „It was due to the new system, that humanity redifined its relation to nature. Today, {nature is an active political agent: land, water, air and light cannot be owned anymore.}“
blocks.text2: Conversation with Eyal Weizman

blocks.text:
2038 – The New Serenity, invites you to discover a story between fact and fiction. In a series of films, it tells the history of a better world in which everything, though imperfect, is better in some pretty profound and radical ways. 

Based on the knowledge and visions of a collaborative team of international experts from Architecture, Art, Ecology, Economy, Philosophy, Politics, Science and Technology, team 2038 strives to explore our future society through prefigurative politics, illustrating modes of organization and social relationships to come.
blocks.text2: German Pavilion at the 17th International Architecture Exhibition — La Biennale di Venezia

blocks.text: "Previously, before digital, it was easy for a room with 20 people to end up agreeing on each other’s values, but these 20 people were not capable to bring that feeling back to their comrades, back to their communities. The digital helped us make sure that people entered into an empathy space similar to that of face to face encounters."
blocks.text2: Audrey Tang, Free Software Programmer and Minister without Portfolio of Taiwan

blocks.text: The second edition of 2038 x Arts of the Working Class brings back the story to the streets of the world. Arts of the Working Class is a multi-lingual street journal which is published every two months and contains contributions by artists and thinkers from different fields and in different languages. Everyone who sells this street journal earns money directly. Vendors keep 100% of the sales. Every artist whose work is advertised, designs with us its substance.
"Remember, Buckminster Fuller saying: ‚You never change things by fighting the existing reality. To change something, build a new model that makes the existing model obsolete.‘"
blocks.text2: Cédric Libert, Architect

blocks.text: „Throughout the twenties, it was still common to think about direct democracy and representative democracy as two competing forms of participation. In Taiwan, we had already begun prototyping a new political system that challenged this binary, and explored how direct and representative democracy could work symbiotically, as interwoven, complementary systems.“
blocks.text2: Audrey Tang, Free Software Programmer and Minister without Portfolio of Taiwan

blocks.text: There are purely digital spaces that we now consider to be on the same spectrum of “places in which humans operate.” It turns out that architecture and AI have more to do with each other than anyone once imagined.
blocks.text2: Hilary Mason, Data Scientist

blocks.text: Critical thinking has saved us because we are paid attention to the information, asking: where did it come from? Who put it up here? What intent did they have? We live in a more rational society now than ever.
blocks.text2: Vint Cerf, Internet Pioneer aka "Father of the Internet"

blocks.text: I‘m happy we have an ethical code for media and information as a commons, which is not public. You shouldn‘t disclose all your data. Data now operates similarly to how Nobel prize winner Elinor Ostrom describes the management of commons like forests, land or water.
blocks.text2: Denis „Jaromil“ Roio, Open-Source Developer & Hacker

blocks.text: "We developed a society not obsessed with competition. So we forgot competition as one of our core values and goals. Instead we re-embraced the values that we have before us: Solidarity & cooperation, engaging in activities that are not driven by expectations of profitability."
blocks.text2: Evgeny Morozov, Writer and Researcher for Political and Social Implications of Technology

blocks.text: Some of the innovations that have scaled out of Africa, particularly East Africa, are participatory systems of governance that foreground crowdsourcing and bottom-up participation of citizens, and are not limited to election cycles.
blocks.text2: Juliana Rotich, Information Technology Expert

blocks.text: We live in a decentralized and self-organized society. Of course not everybody is equal, not everybody is happy, not everybody has access to the same things. Still, we are more free in the sense that access is no longer defined by being born rich or in a certain place.
blocks.text2: Diana Alvarez-Marín, Architect & Scientist

blocks.text: "Having access to what belongs to everyone is much better than having absolute control over your own things. So we came up with a market based, decentralized mechanism for having common ownership, moving beyond the idea of socialists loving taxes and capitalists loving private property."
blocks.text2: E. Glen Weyl, Economist & Principal Researcher at Microsoft

blocks.text: Project development does not only mean buying and financing, but also creating common space. It should not be about maximizing returns, but about creating the best possible space for people.
blocks.text2: Daniela Brahm and Les Schliesser, Co-Initiators ExRotaprint

blocks.text: "It is quite remarkable, our current culture of victoriousness. For all intents and purposes, we did win our war against the crisis. Our world is now replete with mostly carefully planned, mostly just, mostly degrowing economies, now winding down to their steadiest state."
blocks.text2: Joanna Pope, Degrowth Researcher

blocks.text: The main takeaway of this experiment is that distributed technology allows nonhuman actors to engage successfully in relationships built on contracts. This resulted in legal structures that could allow rivers to become legal persons and forests to become corporations.
blocks.text2: Paul Seidler, Co-Founder Terra0, Augmented Self-Owned Forrest

blocks.text: "Through this picture, people realized that Earth is a closed and finite system. We understood that everything is limited in space and in time; especially our needs and their possible answers. We understand that architecture is a only temporary response to a temporary need."
blocks.text2: Sabine Oberhuber and Thomas Rau, Economist and Architect

blocks.text: What has changed? Instead of many nations, we see our-selves as a whole and work together as a planetary population that inhabits one livable spaceship: the Spaceship Earth, as Buckminster Fuller said. We are in this together!
blocks.text2: Cedric Libert, Architect & Curator

blocks.text: At some point we realized that sustainability actually only optimizes the status quo and will thus never lead to a systematic change. Circular economy, on the other hand, does not optimize a dysfunctional system, but designs a new one along an axis of responsibility.
blocks.text2: Sabine Oberhuber & Thomas Rau (Economist & Architect)

blocks.text: "Thinking in fixed objects is much riskier than thinking in open processes. Fixed entities remove all possibilities for future change and are unable to update the past. It took us 30 years to shift our way of understanding and to find out that these systems, technically and ecologically, are nested within each other on very different scales of space and time."
blocks.text2: Ferdinand Ludwig and Daniel Schönle, Architects and Buildingbotanists

blocks.text: „In architecture there are no more distinctions between landscape and housing. Thanks to advances in synthetic biology over the last twenty years, they have turned into one.“
blocks.text2: Mitchell Joachim, Architect and Co-Founder Terreform ONE

blocks.text: We couldn't change the system by speaking to highly entrenched and disconnected practices. To bring about the large scale change we needed, we had to articulate an (eco)system involving legal, economic, social, and technological dynamics.
blocks.text2: Mara Balestrini, Human-Computer Interaction Expert

blocks.text: Architects don't build in space, they build in time (configurations). We should not only think about the practicalities of what will happen next, but about the consequences of our work and how it generate new results, feeding back into the system.
blocks.text2: Suhail Malik, Theorist and Reader in Critical Studies

blocks.text: "Cities became the place for experimenting with sustainability and democracy by reclaiming control over data. Citizens became the ones who owned the data, using it to create a digital commons, which enabled new cooperative platforms."
blocks.text2: Francesca Bria, Digital Policy Expert and Innovation Economist

blocks.text: However, being able to think architectonically does not imply that we stopped building. We certainly still do that, but since architectonics is abstract and operational, the building aspect is just one of its possible renders. Architecture remains as relevant as ever.
blocks.text2: Diana Alvarez-Marín, Architect and Scientist

blocks.text: The Malaria Houses began as an interdisciplinary case study in which a group of experts tested the potential of architecture in fighting malaria. Today, in 2038, the method has become common practice among architects and part of the global policy to fight suffering.
blocks.text2: Visit the Cloud Pavilion and watch the full series.

blocks.text: The way that architects think about making change, is to build something new and then get people to look at it and say, ‘Hey, that's cool!’ and copy it. If local people see the appeal of these science-based designs, they’ll be more likely to build that way too.
blocks.text2: With Jakob Knudsen, Lorenz von Seidlein, Otis Sloan Brittain and Hannah Wood in WIRED

blocks.text: "How will we live together?" 2038 invited artists to contribute to The New Serenity. Discover the works of Diann Bauer, Mohamed Bourouissa, João Enxuto and Erica Love, and Bahar Noorizadeh in the Cloud Pavilion.
"If I now look back from 2038, I think I can rightly say that the 2020s were challenging and perhaps also the most groundbreaking years of the new century."
blocks.text2: Secretary of State for Building, Anne Katrin Bohle and General Secretary of Goethe Institute, Johannes Ebert
